awd_titl_txt: CDI-TYPE II--COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Using Algebraic Topology to Connect Models with Measurements in Complex Nonequilibrium Systems
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. Math Dept.

por.por_cntn:
Complex systems, by their very nature, usually exhibit behaviors that defy easy characterization.  With modern measurement technologies, the behavior of a complex system can often be captured by “brute force” sensing (say by digital imaging), thereby producing enormous data sets spanning a wide range of spatial and temporal scales.  Modern computational technologies allow for the simulations of models incorporating high degrees of realism resulting in huge numerical data sets.  Frequently, the experimental data and model data capture different views of (nominally) the same complex system because data that’s easy to measure in the real world is hard/expensive to obtain in cyberspace and vice versa. Thus, in complex systems research one is often left with no good quantitative answer to the fundamental question: how well does the model describe the observed behavior? This in turn restricts our ability to significantly advance understanding.

Algebraic topology is a branch of mathematics that has been developed to capture robust geometric structures via simple algebraic expressions. The traditional starting point for algebraic topological computations has typically been mathematical objects given in terms of equations.  More recent developments, often referred to as topological data analysis, have focused on using the machinery of algebraic topology where the input is finite data. A primary tool in this domain is persistent homology.

The interdisciplinary, multi-institutional effort funded by this grant extended techniques of topological data analysis and applied these methods to the analysis of a wide range of problems arising in fields as diverse as physics, chemistry, biology, engineering, and the social sciences. The primary focus was the development of the use of persistent homology to reduce complex data, obtained from experiments and simulations associated with the dynamics of convection of fluids, and then to use algebraic topological tools to reconstruct the essential features of the dynamics.  We demonstrated the feasibility of this approach in the context of model systems such as Rayleigh-Benard convection.

To justify the validity of this approach we derived new mathematical results providing bounds on the errors of topological quantities being reported as a function of measurement error.  We also developed softward that is capable of efficiently carrying out algebraic topological computations on large data sets derived from experiments and numerical simulations.

The ideas, techniques, and software developed to carry out this project have found applications in the analysis of dense granular media subject to compression or shear, prediction of compressibility of proteins, and the modeling of propogation of disease in random geometric networks.
